comment.author: 83357281@N00
comment._content: Next to St. Nicholas's Church.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think the 'margarine' basket is there at the corner of the other photo. (History of margarine)

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yes. Looks like the same basket and ducks on ground by the corner of the railings in that other photo.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&ll=53.272422,-9.054228&... The railings were replaced in the 1980's with the railings that use to surround Eyre Square. Everything else is as it was 100years ago. Walked by the very spot earlier this morning.. no ducks!!

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: They just do not look a happy little group do they?

comment.author: 75556178@N05
comment._content:
Lovely photo. James Joyce's partner Norah Barnacle was born about 100 yards from this spot in 1884. One can imagine that she witnessed this scene many times but as she left Galway in 1903 it's unlikely she was in attendance on this occasion. 
Many thanks

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Coming late to this again today but I recognised the location as soon as I saw the photo. It is still a very active market place and one of the best places to be in Galway on a Saturday morning.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Those expressions are priceless, especially the wan in the hat, that face would curdle the cream:-). Great choice of shot Carol, it may not provoke the search of the first version but it is a cracker.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/88162413@N06] It really is great! Sometimes not the same quality as Lawrence or Poole photos, but unbeatable for these kind of spontaneous scenes...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 7430662@N06
comment._content: Looks like a bad time was had by all.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/7430662@N06] But that's the thing about photographs - although it seems unlikely in the case of the woman in black above - they could all have been roaring laughing seconds after this photo was taken...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 7430662@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] My comment was just meant to be humorous and was made in response to their current expressions. It was not meant to convey anything about their lives outside of that one moment that was captured by the camera. I have no doubt like everyone else, their lives  were filled with every emotion in existence, including  happiness.
P.S.
When I take a longer look at the photo nobody actually seems to be having a bad time
they just seem to be minding their own business, the only subject that still stands out (to me) is the little girl with the unusual expression on her face. She doesn't seem unhappy, it just looks like she is looking at something that she finds unsettling or perhaps is eating a piece of sour candy.

comment.author: 64478079@N02
comment._content: wonderful. my hometown.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Ladies seem to be in heavy overcoats, spring or fall perhaps?

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] I'd say they wore that year round.
It is Galway after all.

comment.author: 75556178@N05
comment._content: Hope it was not too cold a day as the young lad on the right was barefoot. Then again Galway lads were always tough.
